sen.j: 鳩山 和夫（はとやま かずお、1856年5月6日（安政3年4月3日 (旧暦)） - 1911年（明治44年）10月3日）は、江戸末期の武士・美作国美作勝山藩士で、明治維新後は政治家、代言人（弁護士）となった。
sen.e: Kazuo HATOYAMA (May 6, 1856, to October 3, 1911) was a samurai, a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain, Mimasaka Province, in the later Edo Period, and a statesman and an advocate (lawyer) afte Meiji Restoration.

Kazuo HATOYAMA (May 6, 1856, to October 3, 1911) was a samurai, a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain, Mimasaka Province, in the late Edo Period, and a statesman and an advocate (lawyer) after Meiji Restoration.

Kazuo HATOYAMA (May 6, 1856, to October 3, 1911) was a samurai, a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain, Mimasaka Province, in the late Edo Period, and a statesman and an advocate (lawyer) after Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 正四位勲三等法学博士。
sen.e: He was a Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank), and had a Doctor of Law.
sen.cmt: 正四位勲三等の定訳不明。
sen.e: He was a doctor of law, with a court rank of the 3rd class of Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank).
sen.cmt: 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: He was a doctor of law, with a court rank of the 3rd class of Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank).

sen.j: 外務次官、衆議院議長を歴任し、教育でも専修学校（現専修大学）の設立に大きく貢献をした大功労者である。
sen.e: He was a man of great merit who successively took the positions of Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs and Chairman of the House of Representatives, and, in the area of education, made a huge contribution to the foundation of Senshu School (present day Senshu University).

He was a man of great merit who successively took the positions of Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs and Chairman of the House of Representatives, and, in the area of education, made a huge contribution to the foundation of Senshu School (present day Senshu University).

He was a man of great merit who successively took the positions of Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs and Chairman of the House of Representatives, and, in the area of education, made a huge contribution to the foundation of Senshu School (present day Senshu University).

sen.j: また、東京専門学校（現、早稲田大学）の校長なども歴任をした。
sen.e: He also took such positions as the headteacher of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (present day Waseda University).
He also took such positions as the president of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (present day Waseda University).
He also took such positions as the president of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (present day Waseda University).

sen.j: 長男は鳩山一郎（政治家､首相）、次男は鳩山秀夫（法学者）である。
sen.e: His eldest son was Ichiro HATOYAMA (stateman, Prime Minister) and his second son was Hideo HATOYAMA (scholar of law).
His eldest son was Ichiro HATOYAMA (statesman, Prime Minister) and his second son was Hideo HATOYAMA (scholar of law).
His eldest son was Ichiro HATOYAMA (statesman, Prime Minister) and his second son was Hideo HATOYAMA (scholar of law).

sen.j: 1856年5月6日、武蔵国江戸虎門（現・東京都港区 (東京都)）に美作国美作勝山藩（現・岡山県真庭市）の藩武士 鳩山博房（江戸留守居役）の4男として生まれる。
sen.e: On May 6, 1856, he was born in Toranomon, Edo, Musashi Province (present day Minato-ku, Tokyo (Tokyo)), as the fourth son of Hirofusa HATOYAMA, a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain Mimasaka Province (present day Maniwa City, Okayama Prefecture).

On May 6, 1856, he was born in Toranomon, Edo, Musashi Province (present day Minato-ku, Tokyo (Tokyo)), as the fourth son of Hirofusa HATOYAMA, a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain Mimasaka Province (present day Maniwa City, Okayama Prefecture), who was in charge of edo rusuiyaku (a person representing the lord during his absence from Edo).

On May 6, 1856, he was born in Toranomon, Edo, Musashi Province (present day Minato-ku, Tokyo (Tokyo)), as the fourth son of Hirofusa HATOYAMA, a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain Mimasaka Province (present day Maniwa City, Okayama Prefecture), who was in charge of edo rusuiyaku (a person representing the lord during his absence from Edo).

sen.j: 1875年、開成学校（現東京大学）を卒業。
sen.e: In 1875, he graduated from Kaisei Shool (present day the University of Tokyo).
In 1875, he graduated from Kaisei Shool (present day the University of Tokyo).
In 1875, he graduated from Kaisei Shool (present day the University of Tokyo).

sen.j: 第一回留学生に選ばれ、米国へ留学。
sen.e: Chosen as the first exchange student, he went to the United States to study.
Chosen as the first exchange student, he went to the United States to study.
Chosen as the first exchange student, he went to the United States to study.

sen.j: コロンビア大学で法学士を取得。
sen.e: He obtained a Bachelor of Law from Columbia University.
He obtained a Bachelor of Law from Columbia University.
He obtained a Bachelor of Law from Columbia University.

sen.j: その後イェール大学（エール大学）で法学博士号を取得する（～明治13年（1880年））。
sen.e: Then he obtained a Doctor of Law from Yale University (～1880).
Then he obtained a Doctor of Law from Yale University (～1880).
Then he obtained a Doctor of Law from Yale University (～1880).

sen.j: 1880年、帰国後、専修学校（現在の専修大学）の設立に大きく貢献、大功労者。
sen.e: In 1880, after returning to Japan, he played a huge role in the foundation of Senshu School (Senshu University), as a person of great merit.
In 1880, after returning to Japan, he played a huge role in the foundation of Senshu School (Senshu University), as a person of great merit.
In 1880, after returning to Japan, he played a huge role in the foundation of Senshu School (Senshu University), as a person of great merit.

sen.j: また代言人・東京帝国大学講師等を歴任。
sen.e: Also he successively took such positions as an advocate and a teacher at the Tokyo Imperial University.
Also he successively took such positions as an advocate and a lecturer at the Tokyo Imperial University.
Also he successively took such positions as an advocate and a lecturer at the Tokyo Imperial University.

sen.j: 1881年11月、旧信州松本藩士である渡辺努の娘・多賀春子と結婚。
sen.e: In November, 1881, he married Haruko TAGA, the daughter of Tsutomu WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Shinshu-Matsumoto Domain.
In November, 1881, he married Haruko TAGA, the daughter of Tsutomu WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Shinshu-Matsumoto Domain.
In November, 1881, he married Haruko TAGA, the daughter of Tsutomu WATANABE, a former feudal retainer of Shinshu-Matsumoto Domain.

sen.j: 1882年2月、東京府会議員に当選。
sen.e: In February, 1882, he was elected to be a member of Tokyo Prefecture Assembly.
In February, 1882, he was elected to be a member of Tokyo Prefecture Assembly.
In February, 1882, he was elected to be a member of Tokyo Prefecture Assembly.

sen.j: 1883年1月、長男・一郎誕生。
sen.e: In January, 1883, his eldest son, Ichiro, was born.
In January, 1883, his eldest son, Ichiro, was born.
In January, 1883, his eldest son, Ichiro, was born.

sen.j: 1884年2月、次男・秀夫誕生。
sen.e: In February, 1884, his second son, Hideo, was born.
In February, 1884, his second son, Hideo, was born.
In February, 1884, his second son, Hideo, was born.

sen.j: 1885年4月、外務省入省。
sen.e: In April, 1885, he joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
In April, 1885, he joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
In April, 1885, he joined the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

sen.j: 外務省書記官、取締局長、東京帝国大学教授に就任。
sen.e: He took the positions of the Secretary of Foreign Affairs, the Director General, and a professor at the Tokyo Imperial University.
He took the positions of the Secretary of Foreign Affairs, the Director General of Enforcement Office, and a professor at the Tokyo Imperial University.
sen.cmt: 取締局:訳抜けですが、定訳不明
sen.e: He took the positions of the Secretary of Foreign Affairs, the Director General of Enforcement Office, and a professor at the Tokyo Imperial University.

sen.j: 1890年7月：東京専門学校（現、早稲田大学）校長に就任。
sen.e: In July, 1890: he became the headteacher of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (present day Waseda University).
In July, 1890: he became the president of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (present day Waseda University).
In July, 1890: he became the president of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (present day Waseda University).

sen.j: 秋頃、小石川区音羽町（現・文京区音羽）に居を移す。
sen.e: In fall, 1890, he moved his residence to Otowa-machi in Koishikawa-ku (present day Otowa, Bunkyo-ku)
In fall, 1890, he moved his residence to Otowa-machi, Koishikawa Ward (present day Otowa, Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo)
In fall, 1890, he moved his residence to Otowa-machi, Koishikawa Ward (present day Otowa, Bunkyo Ward, Tokyo)

sen.j: 1894年3月、衆院選議員に当選。
sen.e: In March, 1894, he was elected to be a member of the House of Representatives.
In March, 1894, he was elected to be a member of the House of Representatives.
In March, 1894, he was elected to be a member of the House of Representatives.

sen.j: 1896年12月、衆議院議長に就任。
sen.e: In December, 1896, he became the chairperson for the House of Representatives.
In December, 1896, he became the chairperson for the House of Representatives.
In December, 1896, he became the chairperson for the House of Representatives.

sen.j: 1897年3月、衆議院本会議で二つの議案で可否同数となったため議長決裁権を行使（2案とも否決）。
sen.e: In March, 1897, he exercised his casting vote when two of the bills were a tie vote at a plenary session of the House of Representatives (both of them were rejected).
In March, 1897, he exercised his casting vote when two of the bills were a tie vote at a plenary session of the House of Representatives (both of them were rejected).
In March, 1897, he exercised his casting vote when two of the bills were a tie vote at a plenary session of the House of Representatives (both of them were rejected).

sen.j: 日本政治史で国会で2回議長決裁権を使ったのは鳩山だけである。
sen.e: HATOYAMA was the only person that has ever used the casting vote of the chairperson twice in the Diet.
HATOYAMA is the only person that used the casting vote of the chairperson twice in the Diet.
sen.cmt: wasをisとし、has everを削除しました
sen.e: HATOYAMA is the only person that used the casting vote of the chairperson twice in the Diet.

sen.j: 1898年9月、外務次官に就任。
sen.e: In September, 1898, he became Vice Minister of Foreing Affairs.
In September, 1898, he became Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs.
In September, 1898, he became Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs.

sen.j: 1902年9月、東京専門学校が早稲田大学となり、早稲田大学校長。
sen.e: In September, 1902, Tokyo Senmon Gakko became Waseda University, and he became the president of Waseda University.
In September, 1902, Tokyo Senmon Gakko became Waseda University, and he became the president of Waseda University.
In September, 1902, Tokyo Senmon Gakko became Waseda University, and he became the president of Waseda University.

sen.j: 1908年11月、東京市会議員に当選、就任。
sen.e: In November, 1908, he was elected to be a member of Tokyo City Assemply.
In November, 1908, he was elected to be a member of Tokyo City Assemply.
In November, 1908, he was elected to be a member of Tokyo City Assemply.

sen.j: 当時の制度によって、衆議院議員は引き続き兼務した。
sen.e: Due to the system those days, he doubled as a member of the House of Representatives.
Due to the system those days, he doubled as a member of the House of Representatives.
Due to the system those days, he doubled as a member of the House of Representatives.

sen.j: 1910年5月、東京弁護士会会長に就任。
sen.e: In May, 1910, he became the chairperson of Tokyo Bar Association.
In May, 1910, he became the chairperson of Tokyo Bar Association.
In May, 1910, he became the chairperson of Tokyo Bar Association.

sen.j: 1911年10月3日、午前7時30分頃、死去。
sen.e: On October 3, 1911, around seven thirty in the morning, he died.
On October 3, 1911, around seven thirty in the morning, he died.
On October 3, 1911, around seven thirty in the morning, he died.

sen.j: 享年55。
sen.e: At the age of 55.
At the age of 55.
At the age of 55.

sen.j: 父・鳩山博房（美作勝山藩士）
sen.e: Father: Hirofusa HATOYAMA (a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain)
Father: Hirofusa HATOYAMA (a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain)
Father: Hirofusa HATOYAMA (a feudal retainer of Mimasaka-Katsuyama Domain)

sen.j: 妻・春子（信州松本藩士・渡辺努の娘）
sen.e: Wife: Haruko (daughter of Tsutomu WATANABE, a feudal retainer of Shinshu-Matsumoto Domain)
Wife: Haruko (daughter of Tsutomu WATANABE, a feudal retainer of Shinshu-Matsumoto Domain)
Wife: Haruko (daughter of Tsutomu WATANABE, a feudal retainer of Shinshu-Matsumoto Domain)

sen.j: 長男・鳩山一郎（政治家、首相）
sen.e: Eldest son: Ichiro HATOYAMA (a statesman, Prime Minister)
Eldest son: Ichiro HATOYAMA (a statesman, Prime Minister)
Eldest son: Ichiro HATOYAMA (a statesman, Prime Minister)

sen.j: 次男・鳩山秀夫（法学者）
sen.e: Second son: Hideo HATOYAMA (a scholar of law)
Second son: Hideo HATOYAMA (a scholar of law)
Second son: Hideo HATOYAMA (a scholar of law)

sen.j: 孫・鳩山威一郎（官僚、政治家）
sen.e: Grandson: Iichiro HATOYAMA (a bureaucrat, statesman)
Grandson: Iichiro HATOYAMA (a bureaucrat, statesman)
Grandson: Iichiro HATOYAMA (a bureaucrat, statesman)

sen.j: 曾孫・鳩山由紀夫（政治家）、鳩山邦夫（政治家）
sen.e: Great-grandchild: Yukio HATOYAMA (a statesman), Kunio HATOYAMA (a statesman)
Great-grandchild: Yukio HATOYAMA (a statesman), Kunio HATOYAMA (a statesman)
